How to use ChatGPT for SEO

I tried ChatGPT for SEO and WOW, impressive! 

Check out this ChatGPT demo video

Watch in real-time as I asked ChatGPT to perform my SEO-related actions.There are a few items in the video that aren’t listed below. For example, in the video, I asked ChatGPT to provide me with some keyword ideas for a couple of industries.

ChatGPT is the rave right now. From writing blog posts, ebooks, or coding, ChatGPT does a good job handling these tasks.

I decided to try it for SEO, and it did a good job.

I first asked ChatGPT to provide me with ten high-volume keywords with a low competition score related to automotive repair and plumbing. Chat GPT got the keywords right regarding the volume, but it failed to provide low-competition keywords. This was expected because other tools specialize in doing this, like SemRush or Ahrefs. After all, I used SemRush to validate ChatGPT’s provided keywords.

Table of Contents

Show me an SEO audit checklist

Here’s what ChatGPT produced: 

Here is a basic SEO audit checklist:

1. Check the website’s accessibility and crawlability:
– Can search engines access and crawl the website?
– Are there any broken links or error pages?
– Is the website mobile-friendly and responsive? 2. Check the website’s content and structure:
– Is the content of the website relevant, informative, and useful?
– Is the content organized in a logical and easy-to-follow structure?
– Are the headings, subheadings, and other tags being used appropriately?
– Is the website using appropriate keywords in the content and meta tags? 3. Check the website’s performance and speed:
– Is the website loading quickly enough?
– Are there any issues with the website’s code or the server that could be causing slow
performance? 4. Check the website’s technical SEO:
– Is the website properly indexed by search engines?
– Are there any duplicate content issues on the website?
– Are the website’s URLs and permalinks structured appropriately?
– Is the website using canonicals and ahrefs tags correctly?

5. Check the website’s backlink profile

What is the code to add Google Analytics to your website?

2. Sign in with your Google account or create a new one.
3. Click “Admin” in the bottom left corner.
4. In the column on the right, click “Tracking Info” and then click “Tracking Code”
5.
The tracking code will be displayed on the page. It should look something like this:
Copy the tracking code and paste it into the HTML of your website, just before the closing

^ tag. Be sure to replace “GA_TRACKING_ID” with your actual
tracking ID.
That’s it! Google Analytics will now track visits to your website. It may take a few hours for

Write a 2,000 word blog post on the importance of SEO.

This is where ChatGPT struggled a little bit.

The AI actually did a very good job producing a relevant post on the subject, however, it fell short of coming anywhere close to the requested 2,000 words. As you can see from these images, I had to ask it to expand on the blog post and make it longer (which is actually pretty cool).

ChatGPT for SEO Summary

I must say, ChatGPT is pretty impressive. I was impressed with the accuracy, speed, and ability to generate most questions I asked it. However, I must stress that when it comes to SEO I wouldn’t completely rely on it, especially for generating blog posts. Why blog posts?

Blog posts are supposed to have character with your own personal touch. Generated AI content is not that. Although professional and accurate, I feel like it lacks the human touch (except for the catchy email subject lines or generated funny emails – those were great). And when it comes to Google and SEO it can be a great tool to use as a starting point or act as a crutch for when/if you develop a brain fog and need some new, fresh ideas. I wouldn’t use it solely as my #1 dependant though. Google likes “helpful content”, thus their recent update entitled just that: Helpful Content Update. Search engines like content that is unique, helpful, and relevant to the user’s search intent, and something tells me that Google (if not now, soon) will be able to sniff out more and more AI-generated content as it continues to soar in popularity. In fact, ChatGPT is getting so popular (while in Beta) that I’m continuously getting an update from them that they’re overloaded. So, the secret is out of the bag.
